item.title: New Brunswick reports record 86 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, active cases rise to 650
item.description: Health officials in New Brunswick are reporting a single-day record 86 new cases of COVID-19 on Monday, as the total number of active cases in the province rises to 650.
item.dc:creator: Allan April

item.title: Nova Scotia reports 96th COVID-19 related death, 83 new cases over the weekend
item.description: Health officials in Nova Scotia are reporting 83 new cases of COVID-19 over the weekend, along with 46 recoveries, as the number of active cases in the province rises to 205.
item.dc:creator: Allan April

item.title: 'Residents are dying alone,' nursing home workers ask for wage increase to help staffing crisis
item.description: During a virtual news conference on Monday, the union representing workers in many of New Brunswick's nursing homes is urging premier Blaine Higgs to fix the current "staffing crisis" in nursing homes across the province.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Basa
item.enclosure: The president of the New Brunswick Council of Nursing Home Unions, which represents 51 of 70 nursing homes in the province, says several locations across the province have been operating with 50 per cent of their staff or less, which doesn't allow them to prioritize those in their care.

item.title: N.S to release daily details on schools affected by COVID-19 starting Tuesday
item.description: Elizabeth Guitard kept her kids home from school Monday, concerned over the growing list of COVID-19 exposures linked to Nova Scotia schools.
item.dc:creator: Heidi Petracek
item.enclosure: According to one parent, at least one school affected by multiple exposures is now taking extra measures. One parent whose child attends Halifax West says she received four separate notifications about cases connected to the school.

item.title: Gathering criticism: fears Dal party may lead to COVID-19 surge
item.description: Reaction continues to roll-in tonight from a raucous street party near Dalhousie University in Halifax over the weekend, but there are fears the long-term consequences could affect the entire province.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Frisko
item.creditLine: CTV News Atlantic Reporter and Host

item.title: Volunteers surge in N.S. to help with testing as fourth wave of COVID-19 arrives
item.description: As a fourth wave crashes into communities across Canada, volunteers are helping to build part of Nova Scotia's protective wall.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Plowman

item.title: Halifax mayor says rowdy university partiers lacked common sense in light of COVID-19
item.description: Dalhousie University students who attended a massive party that violated COVID-19 protocols should use more common sense -- and stay away from classes for one week and get tested, authorities say.
item.dc:creator: The Canadian Press

item.title: Not everyone feels new virtual care pilot program in Nova Scotia will work for them
item.description: There are more than 70,000 people without a family doctor in Nova Scotia, but soon people in the province will have the option to see a physician virtually.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Moore
item.enclosure: The province is planning to spend $1.3 million to expand the virtual care pilot program to the health authority's central and eastern zones starting in December, after the program launched in the northern and western zones last spring.

item.title: N.B. nursing home unions seek $4 per hour wage hike to address labour shortages
item.description: The New Brunswick Council of Nursing Home Unions is calling on the provincial government to increase wages for workers in long-term care homes in an effort to address a "crippling" staffing shortage that they say is leaving seniors with inadequate care.
item.dc:creator: The Canadian Press
item.enclosure: The New Brunswick Council of Nursing Home Unions is calling on the provincial government to increase wages for workers in long-term care homes by $4 per hour. (File photo)

item.title: DNA evidence ties blood of alleged jail-beating victim to clothing of N.S. inmates
item.description: Prosecutors in the trial of inmates accused of attempting to murder a prisoner in his Nova Scotia jail cell have introduced DNA evidence linking the victim's blood to three of the alleged assailants' clothing.
item.dc:creator: The Canadian Press
item.enclosure: The Central Nova Scotia Correctional Facility yard is seen in Dartmouth on Tuesday, May 15, 2018. (THE CANADIAN PRESS/Andrew Vaughan)
